H0.text: Photosynthesis is the process that plants use to produce food, using oxygen, carbon dioxide, ATP, and NADPH as reactants.

H1.text: Glycolysis is the process that plants use to produce food, in which oxygen, carbon dioxide, ATP, and NADPH act as reactants.

H2.text: Absorbtion is the process in which oxygen, carbon dioxide, ATP, and NADPH are reactants that plants use to produce food.

H3.text: Chlorophyll is the process that uses oxygen, carbon dioxide, ATP, and NADPH as reactants for plants to produce food.

A4.text: Oxygen is a waste product of light-dependent reactions

A5.text: the light-independent reactions use these products to capture and reduce carbon dioxide

A6.text: the source of oxygen produced by photosynthesis

A7.text: Glycolysis produces adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH)

A8.text: NADPH is used in biosynthetic processes such as fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis, not as a reactant in glycolysis
